Name: Everest
Description:
The players race for conquering Mt. Everest. The game features a 3d mountain with the East, Southwest and North faces of Everest.

The players may choose to begin either in Kathmandu or Lhasa. Players advance by rolling a die. The approach march takes place on the flat part of the board and once you have reached your base camp you may again choose between longer and shorter, but more risky, routes to the summit.

There are three kinds of event cards, for approach march, camp and climbing events. A card is drawn when a player lands on a marked space or a camp. There are both good and bad events to advance or delay the conquest.

When climbing players must set up 4 camps and go back and forth between them to "acclimatize". Aluminum ladders and safety ropes may be set up by successful die roll to get over chasms and evil spots. Once the player enters the Death Zone (over 8000 m) oxygen tanks are needed. In case all oxygen is consumed without the player being able to reach the summit, she must return to previous camp to get more. The first player back at base camp after summiting Everest is the winner.

Name: Bible Search: Sunday School Edition
Description: Bible Search – Sunday School Edition is a trivia game for children of all ages.  Players ask each other questions extracted from better-known Bible stories.  A die is tossed by each player on his or her turn to determine the question category and degree of difficulty of the question to be answered.  For each correct answer, a player may place one of his or her pawns on the game board, or remove an opponent’s pawn.  The first player to place three pawns in a row wins the game.  The game includes a game board, cards with 3000 questions and answers, pawns in four different colors, a die, and instructions.

Name: Cats in the Fish Shop!
Description:
From the box:
"Each player is given a cat. The cats lick their lips and lurk around the fish stall. When the fishmonger isn't looking, they try to steal a fish.
This is an exciting game for all children who can be crafty."

Name: Belankai
Description:
Alternative names for this gambling game are Belankas or Belankai, though I more often hear it described as the latter. Belankas is the Malay name for the King Crab, one of the pictures featured in the game.

The game consists of a four-sided tee-totum. Modern Belankai spinners are made from a thin wooden dowel that runs through a cuboid piece of plastic with the pictures engraved on four sides. The pictures are a king crab, a flower/star/coin (hard to tell - the pictures are all stylized), a fish and a prawn (c.f. Hoo Hey How).

A staking board is drawn on any large piece of paper (or the ground) showing the four symbols. Players stake on the pictures and the banker (who will claim the stakes or pay winnings) spins the tee-totum in wide dish and covers it with a bowl. When the tee-totum comes to rest, it is revealed and players are payed according to whichever picture has come to rest on top.

Dobree describes that a plate of rice is often to be found where this game is played - it is used to hold the dish where the tee-totum is spun and serves to steady the dish and deaden  the sound of the top when it is spinning.

Name: Hoo Hey How
Description:
Hoo Hey How is a Chinese dice game with similarities to Crown and Anchor dice. This gambling game consists of three dice with six different pictures on their sides and a paper board marked with the same six pictures for stakes to be placed on them. This board could be self-drawn but you can get printed boards together with the dice nowadays.

The name, Hoo Hey How, is derived from the Hokkien names of three of the things that usually appear on the dice = a fish (Hoo), a prawn (Hey) and a king crab (How). However, modern dice tend to show ordinary crabs.

Dobree, in the 1950s, described the objects commonly depicted on the dice: a fish, a prawn, a king crab, a flower, a butterfly, a beautiful lady. But he also noted that other pictures could also appear: a cat, a mouse, a cock, a centipede, a tiger, an elephant, a gourd, three coins (Chinese cash).

Today, the dice tend to show more standard pictures and the selection of pictures is standardized for the region where they originate too. For example, the dice in Malaysia and Singapore (and I assume Hong Kong, where many of them are made) depict a fish, a prawn, a crab, a Chinese coin, a gourd and a cockerel. Thai Hoo Hey How dice (called Nam Tou Bu Bak [please excuse my bad transliteration]) have a tiger instead of a coin, as do dice from the Malaysian state of Sabah, but the Sabah dice show the head of the tiger rather than the whole animal. In Vietnam, they are called Bau Cua Tom Ca and often played at the new year: the distinguishing feature is a stag instead of a coin. Another feature is that the dice may be made of cardboard.

Many variants are possible, some that do not even feature the Hoo, Hey or How, so I don't know what they would be called. From Penang in Malaysia, I have dice that feature an elephant, a rabbit, a butterfly, a snake, a centipede and a flower. In Singapore, some older dice I have feature mahjong dragons together with symbols of political parties from the 1950s.

To play, one player takes the role of banker and the others are punters. Players stake money on the betting board and the dice are cast (either under cover or into a porcelain bowl). Punters are paid an equivalent amount that they staked, the number of times their picture appears on the dice (e.g. if someone bet on the fish and it appears twice, the punter gets back twice their stake).

This game is similar to The Game of Crown and Anchor.

Name: Zhuang Yuan Chou
Description:
Zhuang Yuan Chou (Chong Yuen Chow in Cantonese) is a gambling game using dice and tallies, first mentioned in Chinese texts in the late 18th century, but still played today.

'Zhuang Yuan' is the title given to the scholar who achieved the highest distinction in the imperial examinations that determined entry into the Chinese bureaucracy.

The game consists of six dice and sixty-three tallies bearing titles of ranks of achievement in the examinations and the number of points they are worth. There is only one each of the top 3 positions, of which the highest value (32 points) and the largest tally is the Zhuan Yuan. 
The lower the position, the thinner/shorter the tallies and the fewer points each is worth. At the lowest rank, Xiu Cai, there are 32 tallies worth 1 point each. As with many Chinese dice games, a porcelain bowl is often used to hold and roll the dice.

To play, punters agree on a value per point (Dobree mentions 1 cent, 10 cents or 50 cents). Each player takes turns rolling all six dice. According to the roll, the player is allowed to claim tallies of equivalent worth from the center of the table where they are initially placed. Certain rolls allow one to claim tallies from other players if those tallies were previously claimed. The game is played until all tallies have been claimed.

The best roll is six of a kind, allowing the player to claim all the tallies, whether they are in the pool or with other players. Five of a kind allows the player to claim the Zhuan Yuan tally wherever it is. Red fours (on Chinese dice, the one and four spots are red) are also good to roll - four of them will also get you the Zhuan Yuan tally. Dobree and Culin have both described the game including the values of the rolls.

In the past, tallies were made of bone and hand-engraved. Modern sets have brightly colored plastic tallies and can be found for sale in Mahjong shops in Singapore (and likely elsewhere).

Name: The Richest Christian
Description:
Learn what the Bible says about money.

Players spin and move their pieces. Each space is a positive or negative behavior and an associated Bible verse.  Good behaviors are blessed with money, foolish behaviors pay penalties.  At the beginning of their turn before they move, a player may choose to draw an "Opportunity" card.  This is an opportunity to bless someone else, and involves giving away a certain amount of money to someone in need.  In return, the player will earn "Treasures in Heaven".  If a player cannot afford to pay the amount on the Opportunity card, they must pay a smaller fee for not wisely managing their finances.  The first player to collect a set amount of Treasures (different based on the number of players) is the winner.

Bonus cash awards go to those who can quote the verses from memory, have read the Bible recently and those who learned something from a Bible teacher recently.

Name: Zambeln
Description:
Zambeln is a game supposedly played by teddy bears and other living toys. It is an extra to the Plüsch, Power and Plunder (PP&P) Role-Playing-Game in which toy pets come to life, and comes with the scenario "Plüsch, Drugs & Rock'n Roll."
Effectively, it is much like Uno, where every player plays a card per turn, which has to match the card played before; with some special card effects added, and two discard piles. First player to lose all his cards wins.

Name: Heroscape Expansion Set: Thora's Vengeance
Description:
Thora's Vengeance  is the fifth Small Expansion Set (wave 5) in the HeroScape series.

There are 4 boosters:

     Ninjas & Samurai
     Soulborgs
     Warriors & Soulborgs
     Gladiators & Agents


Each pack contains 6-7 new figures, army unit cards and some terrain pieces, but no glyphs.

Name: Burger Party
Description: Players are employees in a hamburger restaurant. They will have to take an order from one of the tables, put up the parts of the ordered meal and take it to the customer. The fastest waiter wins.

Name: Four Battles of Army Group South
Description:
"Four Battles of Army Group South" consists of four completely separate regimental/divisional level wargames, each with its own 17" x 22" five-color map, unit counters and rules.

All four games use a set of Standard Rules derived from Panzergruppe Guderian as the basic core game rules.  Each game then, has it's own set of Exclusive rules.

Kiev: The Battle of Encirclement, 1941, is a simulation of the German Blitzkrieg campaign from 29 August to 26 September 1941.  It ended with the largest encirclement in history: 665,000 Soviets were destroyed; 3718 guns and 884 armored fighting vehicles captured; and the remains of the great Soviet prewar army of April 1941 was finished as a fighting force.
2 days per turn, 5 miles / 8 kilometers per hex.

Rostov: The First Soviet Counter-Attack, 1941, depicts the German drive across the Donets Basin in the fall of 1941.  Army Group South, accompanied by various Axis-Allied Armies, attempted to seize the valuable communications junction at Rostov and establish bridgeheads across the Donets and lower Don rivers.  In the fighting around Rostov, the Germans suffered their first strategic setback in their campaign against Russia, as the Soviet Army drove the German mechanized spearhead from this vital area. 
2 days per turn, 10.5 miles / 17 kilometers per hex.

Operation Star: The Soviet Winter Offensive, 1943, the Soviet offensive towards Kharkov and Dnepr in February 1943 and the German counterattack that followed.  Strong Soviet forces attempted to take Kharkov and sweep to the south and west, cutting off all of Army Group Don.  Von Manstein formulated a daring counter-operation that called for the aggressive use of all available Panzer reserves. 
5 days per turn, 6.5 miles / 10.5 kilometers per hex.

Korsun: The German Pocket on the Dniepr, 1944, depicts the battle of the encirclement - known to the Soviets as the Korsun Pocket and to the Germans as the Cherkassy Pocket - fought in late January and early February 1944, the largest German pocket since Stalingrad, only half the trapped German soldiers escape. 
2 days per turn, 4.6 miles / 7.5 kilometers per hex.

Last in the series of Series: Quads (SPI).

Game Inventory:
Four 17 x 22" five-color mapsheets
Two dual-side printed countersheets (800 1/2" counters)
Two 8-page Army Group South Standard Rules rulebooks
Two 4-page Army Group South Charts & Tables booklets
Four 4-page game specific rulebooks
One 8-page AGS Historical Background booklet
One 6-sided die

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 3 - 4 hours

Name: Travel America
Description:
A Jacmar Electric Game for All Ages

TRAVEL AMERICA is equipped with 6 cards printed on both sides, each side containing 12 interesting illustrations and 12 descriptions.

The electric panel has 24 stations.  Place the card selected for play on the 2 protruding panel guides at the top of the platform.  Hold the selector tip in the left hand and place on the contact station selected for play.  The other tip is help in the right hand and placed on contact stations until the lamp lights up.  The electric panel is is operated on a 1.5 volt dry cell battery easily replaced.  Interesting fascinating and educational for all ages.

Name: The Buccaneers: A Sea-Faring Game of Adventure
Description:
From the cover:
THE BUCCANEERS, a Seafaring Game of Adventure for 2 to 6 players, based on the popular TV program, is a game of strategy and skill that youngsters of 7 to 15 find absorbing get-together fun. The friendly rivalry of "Pirates" against "King's Men" offers the exciting competitive play recommended by child psychologists for growing-up years. Every game plays differently and is bound to capture the attention of even the most active children for a period of quieter play.

Planning moves on the action-packed "sea" board in order to capture the most "Buccaneer Treasure" develops mental concentration and encourages social responsiveness through the opportunity for team play. Ideal for an after-school get-together, family play hours and other recreational moments.

Ships move from their own Start Corner to their own Finish Corner by role of dice. Along the path if they land directly on a "Pick up Treasure" space, they may do so. Treasure chests are vary in value and the value remains secret until the game ends. If they land directly on one of their opponent's ship, they "Cannonade", taking off a mast from the opponent's ship. If all three masts are removed, the ship is sunk and any treasure it had goes to the other side. The game ends when all of the Treasure Chests have been sailed off the board or one side has all of its ships sunken. Winner has the greatest value from their treasure.

Name: Magic Words
Description: The game is played by teams of 2 players. The idea is to find 3-4 words crossing each other and set these words in a 5*5 grid as fast as possible. Winning of a round produces a point. The first team to gather 5 points wins.

Name: Chicago Sports Trivia Game
Description:
Chicago Sports Trivia contains 2,020 questions on 505 cards in 4 categories: Chicago Cubs, Chicago White Sox, Chicago Bears and All Sports (which includes Bulls, Black Hawks, Sting and college sports).

Players attempt to correctly answer as many questions as possible to be the first player to reach the WINNER box.

Name: Ett skepp kommer lastat
Description:
This is a word game where there are 25 squares on the board and the idea is to fill them with colored tokens. The squares show different topics such as birds, countries or fruits. The player spins on a wheel with letters and the letter that the spinner stops on should be the initial letter of the word you are competing for. When you come up with a word you say it aloud and throw a small ball into the box. If there are more players who says a word at the same time, it is the ball that comes at the bottom that wins. For each win you have to mark the box and the one that first succeeds in marking 10 squares or most if all 25 squares are marked wins.

The name of the game translates into English as 'The ship is loaded'.

Name: Hockey Night
Description: A trivia game about ice hockey published to promote Finnish ice hockey TV-program Hockey Night. There are 900 questions and answers included.

Name: L33T Tiles
Description:
L33T Tiles are a replacement tile set for ScrabbleÂ® and other word games, based on internet slang known as leetspeak. The letter distribution has been modified and extensively tested for optimal play using leet words in the add-on dictionary.

Each set of L33T Tiles comes with 103 tiles, a satin pouch and a manual with additional rules for gameplay. The tiles are colored to emulate a classic terminal window, and the manual is printed on a genuine IBM punch card.

Home Page: http://www.leettiles.com/

Name: Topfgucker
Description:
Your cook wants to deliver variable soups at first. Roll the die , move your cook around a Kalaha like board. Try to get the to the hotplates and if the right ingredients are there you can lay down one of your 9 cards with different soup recipes you get in the beginning of the game. The first one who completes all of his soups is the "Meisterkoch".

This game is a re-themed and redeveloped version of Auf Fotosafari in Ombagassi.

Name: Carrot Race
Description:
Collect carrots with your hare from the 'garden' and bring them back to the burrow (the starting point). Once there you receive a carrot card, but keeps it face down until the end of the game.

There are 3 kinds of carrots: 

    rotten (no points at the end of the game), 
    unripe green (1 point) and 
    ripe red carrots (2 points). 


The player with the most points wins.

It is also possible to win and lose carrots during the game in the two next situations:

1. If a hare with a carrot and a hare without a carrot meet on the same square, they must roll the die to determine who keeps the carrot.

2. If you collect 3 lettuce cards (you get these when you are on a square with a lettuce symbol), you will win a carrot card from the player with the most cards.

Name: Wizard Wars
Description:
Maug the Wizard-King is dead.  You are one of his apprentices, skilled in the dark arts and in the arts of sorcery.  Summon minions to fight your battles, wield earthshaking magics.  Vie for control of ancient libraries, pools of magical power, and mighty fortresses.  Then, when the time is right, take the Diamond Throne for your own!

Each apprentice has a different deck of spells available.  These are not only thematic, but give different sorts of abilities.  Wizards going on quests can find magic items.  The Regent must be deposed from the throne first, then the throne held for three full turns to win.  Meanwhile, the peasants will attack whoever currently holds the throne.

Game contains a rolled up laminated color board, player mats, and cardstock counters, tent-folded figures, a spell deck for each player, and monster and item cards.

Name: Gold Broker: Y2K Collectors Edition
Description: In this Monopoly-like game, players compete to be the first to double their net worth by rolling the dice and moving around a board buying properties and investing in gold.  As in Monopoly, players have to pay each other rent when they land on owned properties, but this game focuses more on the fluctuating price of gold and takes advantage of the Y2K scare by including "Y2K Crash" spaces that cause money to be lost and "Computer Whiz" spaces where money is earned for fixing Y2K bugs.

Name: Correspo!
Description:
Correspo! is a game for young children. In the box you’ll find 54 large square colorful, lavishly hand-illustrated picture cards , plus 54 large number cards. The number cards are for more advanced games school-age children can play.
Each Correspo! box contains not one, but five games! Five games for five different age groups from 18 months to 7 years old. Numerous variations make it possible for parents to modify the five basic games for more players, for a child to play alone, for parent/child or child/child games, etc.

Some are memory games, while others of an educational nature exercise the player’s knowledge of words and numbers. Another game is built around children’s lively imaginations, while the last one simply requires luck and quick reactions.

Name: Thomas & Friends: All Aboard! Card Game
Description: Thomas & Friends: All Aboard! Card Games is designed for children ages 3 to 7.  It comes with a deck of 48 cards; 12 cards in each of the four colors (blue, red, green, and yellow).  Each color has a set of 12 characters from the Thomas the Tank Engine stories. The deck comes with the rules for three games that can be played with the cards: Thomas Go Fish, Thomas Memory, and Thomas SNAP games.
Families: TV Shows: Thomas the Tank Engine

Name: Jibi: Who's the Ace Reporter
Description:
To file the best scoop with the morning paper: the player who puts together the best story without getting scooped is declared the ace reporter.

Jibi is a family game. This action-adventure game is built around the concept of creating photo stories. The players have to move their pieces around the labyrinthine island of Jibos to collect photos to compile and complete their stories.

In the game, cards representing people and places on the island of Jibos are picked or taken from other players. The object is to collect pairs and sets of photo cards. Special Jibi cards set the pace of the action from start to finish of each game. Although Jibi is a game of strategy, luck also comes into play from time to time &#8211; for better or worse!

WHO WILL BE THE ACE REPORTER?

Name: Big League Baseball
Description: A baseball game that is spinner-activated. The spinner and all four-color charts come on one heavy-duty cardboard base. Underlying the spinner is a printed disk divided into pie sections containing realistic percentages of singles, doubles, triples, home runs, walks, strikeouts, fly outs, out-at-first (and a thin sliver for a possible triple play). Also on same gameboard, four charts: Nobody on Base, 1 on Base, 2 on Base, 3 on Base. Each chart gives results for 0, 1, or 2 outs and contains various results including: hit-by-pitch, 2-base error, out stretching a single into a double, out at 2nd, out at 3rd, five levels of double-plays, caught stealing, stolen base, one-base error, four levels of singles results, pick-off, fielder's choice, balk, passed ball, or wild pitch. Game comes with 9 plastic pegs to keep track of action. Peg charts include Runs Scored, Innings Played, Outs, and Batters (one peg on either side of home plate). Comes with two-sided "Spinner Results" sheet which lists explanations for all abbreviations describing play outcomes.

Name: Útvegsspilið
Description:
Útvegsspilið (The Fishery Game) could probably only be made in Iceland!
Your object is to buy ships to fish, build fish factories, bring the fish to the factories and sell it and thus make as much money as you possibly can.
The further you sail while fishing, the more money you can make, but the risk is more of not making it back to the factories and of losing  it all in the process!
The winner is the one who has the most money after a agreed upon time (1 to 3 hours), or when someone gets the last money from the bank!

Name: Ponytrail
Description:
Inside a wooden box there are 28 Horses, pieces of horse dung, question cards, a sand timer, a big board and a lot more, mostly made of wood.

Each player has to gain a small herd of Ponies and make more money out of them. Thematically at the horse farm you undergo the ups and downs of a farmer and breeder of ponies.

Different levels make it possible to play it with kids or play it more strategically.

Name: Fantom Electronic
Description:
2 or 4 players can play the game in 5 grades of difficulty.

On a board with 7 x 7 squares each player has a number of meeples in a starting line. The object is to get to the other side. The specal effect of "Fantom electronic" is the "Fantom field" - a special "hidden" space which is wandering around. This movement is done by the small computer-unit at the one side of the board. There are different acoustic hints where this field can be and in which direction it wanders, so you have to calculate it. If you manage to step on this space with one of your meeples, you can do another step.

So it's not much strategy but calculating and deduction ...

Name: 19th Hole Golf
Description:
19th Hole Golf is the original, championship golf-dice game; selected as a tournament golf-favorite: at the PGA Seniors, the Ryder Cup, the Dinah Shore LPGA, the Johnny Miller Classic, and many other major tour events.

19th Hole Golf is an authentic game of golf played with dice. Each roll of the dice plays a hole. All of the dice are rolled at once. You can play medal play (the player with the fewest total number of strokes at the end of play) or match play contests (the player who wins the most holes).

You can play team against team, with a point scored for the low ball and 1 point for the team with low total. Any number of players can play 19th Hole Golf.

Name: Geography Lotto
Description: This educational game uses six small individual cards, each depicting 8 states.  Players match up smaller state cards, with information about each state on the back, to their boards.

Name: Skatterbug
Description: Wind up a top and have it spin to knock as many discs in holes as possible to score different point values.

Name: King O' Kings
Description:
The board is set up something like a plus sign.  The center area is called "The Arena" and it is 4x4 grid with alternating black & white squares like a chessboard.  On each side there is a 3 x 4 "Safety Zone" which serves as the starting area for each player.  The safety zones are also arranged with alternating squares, although the squares are gray and the color of your pieces.
Pieces move diagonally away from their "safety zone".  No piece may enter any safety zone once it has entered The Arena. The goal is to move your pieces into the arena and create kings.  
Initially, all pieces are "pawns" and can move only diagonally forward (away from their safety area).  Once they enter the arena, they can move diagonally in any direction but may not leave the arena.
A player may create a "prince" by landing on an opponent's pawn with one of his pawns.  The stack of two pieces can then move either 1 or 2 spaces, still diagonally, but may move forwards or backwards.  It may not enter any safety zone (it must remain in the arena).
A player creates a king when his prince takes a pawn or his pawn takes a prince (princes may not take each other).  A king is a stack of three pieces.  Once formed kings are removed to the scoring area.
The game ends when there is no possibility of additional kings being made.  The winner is the player who has the most kings.
Note that while the game says it will play 2-4 there are no rules offered for any number other than 4.

Name: Spin-A-Shape
Description:
From the box: "Children are introduced to basic geometrical shapes as they have fun playing 4 different games. The colorful graphics of familiar, everyday objects make it easy for young game players to understand and enjoy."

All games are variants on using a spinner to tell you which of your cardboard pieces to put into your cardboard frame.

Name: Football Fever
Description:
Football Fever is as the title implies a football (soccer) game in which 2-6 players compete for the championship by means of football knowledge and playing matches against each other.

The game plays much like Monopoly in that, players will roll 2 dice and move around a circular playing field. However there are no properties to buy, instead players will have to answer football related questions, play matches, play set pieces (ie. penalty kick, free kick etc.) or gain bonuses in the shape of cards that'll give them an advantage in the aforementioned matches.

Football matches are played out on the middle of the board, and uses a colored die to determine the movement of the ball and subsequently the success of attempts on goal. matches are timed with a tiny hourglass.

The player to first reach 15 points on the scoreboard by answering trivia questions AND reach 3 match victories is declared winner.

Name: Bullspit
Description: Bull Spit is the PBR version of the classic bluffing game. Like Liar's Dice and dollar poker, the key is to bluff what cards are in your hand, and what you say you are discarding. "Take the Bull by the Horns" and watch out for those jokers as you bid and bluff your way to victory!

Name: Tripoto
Description:
Tripoto is a wooden regular tetrahedron, with six holes on every face.

Players take turns putting (or moving, or removing) their fingers into the holes. The player(s) who obtain(s) three of his/her/their fingers in-a-row is/are the winner(s) (!).

An interesting mix between abstract strategy and dexterity games. Very fun, also for people watching the game.

Name: Yvette Fielding's Ghosts
Description:
In the pitch black of a silent room, the only sound is the pulsating beat of your pounding heart. You are about to embark on the investigation of a lifetime, to go where no other mortal soul has ever dared to tread.
Yvette Fielding’s Ghosts is a game where intrepid investigators search for the answer to the ultimate question:

IS THERE REALLY LIFE AFTER DEATH?

No two investigations are the same! Whether you’re an investigator or a ghost, you’re in the thick of the action, sharing dark and dangerous corridors, walking through imposing doors, wondering just what – if anything – will be captured tonight!
Using specialist equipment, the investigators’ ultimate goal is to gather documentary evidence of a ghost and to prove its identity. But investigators need to beware, they only have one night and time is fast running out.
Ghosts must try to avoid capture by using special tactics such as scaring an investigator to another part of the building or possessing them and their equipment! Meanwhile, they walk through walls and play gruesome tricks on anyone who gets too close to the truth.
Ghosts is not for the faint-hearted! You are about to become one of the Antix crew or something from another plane and now only one question remains:

ARE YOU BRAVE ENOUGH TO PLAY?

Name: Campbell's Soup Game
Description:
Licensed by Campbell’s Soup Company, “Campbell’s Soup Game” is a children’s game for ages 3 and up, for 2-4 players.  It includes a spinner, alphabet letter tokens (which are round, and the writing on them resembles soup noodles), plus two-sided round discs to serve as Campbell’s Soup Bowls, according to the package.

The label on the container has text in both English and French, and on the bottom label has information for Mattel USA, Mattel France, Mattel Australia and Mattel Canada.  The container itself is shaped very much like a soup can.  It is unclear if the mechanics or game play of this game differs at all from the 1979 title, “Campbell's Alphabet Scoop & Spell”, which also came in a soup-shaped container, and was produced by Warren Industries.

Name: Bugs! Bugs! Bugs!
Description:
This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series from Patch Products.

During a turn, a player draws a card.  If that player draws a bug card, he takes the matching bug finger puppet and puts it on a finger.  If he draws an ant, the turn is over.  If the player draws a stinkbug, he must take the stinkbug, even from another player.  The winner is the person who has the most bugs but does not have the stinkbug.

Name: Fluttery Butterflies
Description: This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins line of games by Patch Products.  Players take turns drawing a card from a central deck.  If this card is a butterfly, you take the matching butterfly and place it on your plower.  If the card is a caterpillar, you do nothing.  If you draw the moth card, you take the moth (even from another player) and place it on your flower.  The winner is the first player to have five butterflies on their flower and not have the moth.

Name: Tiny Tins Charades
Description: This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series by Patch Products.  It is a child oriented game based on the classic charades with the categories limited to Books, Songs, Movies, TV Shows, and Quotes.  Included in the rules are some nice instructions on how to signal your ideas to your teammates.  The game is played in two minutes increments by alternating teams until one team reaches 15 points.

Name: Alien Race in Outer Space
Description:
This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series by Patch Products.

Players take turns rolling two dice.  One determines which of six aliens to move, the other determines how far it will move.  When an alien lands on or passes through your home system, you can take a matching token (but only once).  The winner is the first player to have a token from each of the six aliens.

Name: Go Speed Go!
Description:
This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series by Patch Products.

Each players takes a race car that they are trying to move around the track.  The winner is the first person across the finish line.  Movement is determined from marbles dropped into the pole position construct, which is a lot like a dice tower.

Name: Dozen Dice Games
Description:
This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series by Patch Products.

This game comes with rules for a dozen different dice games as well as the neccessary six, eight, and ten-sided dice.  The games included are:

21!
High die, high die, high die, ho!
Chase the Ace
Straight up to 100
Ship/Captain/Crew
Liar's Dice
Hacker's golf
Rock around the clock
Sinister six
Dead die 96
Bean your neighbor
Yacht race

Name: Today I Went to the Market
Description:
This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series by Patch Products.

This is basically a board game version of I Spy.  Players look at the board and say "Today I went to the market and saw something . . ."  Other players then try to guess what the player saw.  If you guess correctly, you get one of the grocery tokens.  If no one guesses correctly, then you get a token.  The game ends when all of the tokes are gone, with the winner being the player with the most tokens.

Name: Ha-Ha Hair-do!
Description:
This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series by Patch Products.

Each player is trying to collect a certain color of hair clips.  On each turn, the player spins.  If he spins take, he takes a hari clip of his color.  If he spins put back, he must put one back in the center.  If he spins Sparkly Headband, he takes possession of the Sparkly Headband, even from another player.  The first player to have all four of his hair clips and the Sparkly Headband is the winner.

This is part of the Big Deal series of card games by Patch Products.

Players divide the deck evenly and take turns laying out three cards at a time.  If all three cards match by number or symbol, they take the cards, plus any under them, and place them in there score pile.  Sevens are wild and match anything.  If you do not match, your cards stay out there, and the next player plays his three cards on top of them.  The winner is the player with the most point cards when all of the cards are used.

Name: Frontline
Description:
(From publisher's website:) Frontline is a dynamic wargame for 2 players. During WW2, five soldiers are on a reconnaissance mission near a newly discovered enemy base, as they stumble upon a small squad of enemy soldiers..

Supply your team of 5 soldiers with weapons and tools and send them into battle. Try to use the dynamic landscape to ambush your opponent, or use hit and run tactics to weaken the other squad, before going in to deliver the final blow..

Name: Combinatorix Jr
Description:
Mandala style, with ever changing patterns.
 A gracefully proportioned subset of Combinatorix, this group of squares, equilateral triangles, hexagons, and isosceles right triangles has its own 40-page booklet of explorations, designs and games.

Approximately 55 wood tiles have 1" unit sides, are 1/4" thick for easy handling, and mix four colors in all-different assortments within the 11" rounded triangular tray. No two sets are exactly alike. Display stand included. For 1 to 3 players, ages 6 to adult.

For 1 to 3 players, ages 6 to adult.
Families: Versions & Editions: Junior Versions of Grown-Up Games

Name: GrandSlam Baseball
Description:
This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series by Patch Products.

Players take turns batting and fielding as in real baseball.  There are three decks of cards -- pitching, hitting, and fielding -- that determine what occurs in the game.  The winner is the player with the most points after nine innings.

Name: Nalle Puh ja tuulinen päivä
Description: Winnie the Pooh and his friends are trying really hard to stay on the path while the wind is blowing really strongly. The Players throw a colored die and move the figures on a board that may fall anytime. Therefore the players have to think carefully, which figure to move, for if the board falls the player loses all his honey. The winner is the player who at the end still has any honey tokens after all the others have lost theirs'.

Name: Fuzzy Puppy
Description:
This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series by Patch Products.

Two players (or two teams) take turns spinning and then moving their puppy around the circle.  If you land on the other puppy, you collect one of the four items you need to win the game.  The winner is the first player to collect a bone, bowl, bed, and ball.

Name: Bang! Zoom!
Description:
This is part of the Big Deal series of card games by Patch Products.

Players start with six cards each, which are used to spell words.  The first person to spell BANG gets a 10 point bonus.  Once this occurs, when someone spells ZOOM, they get a 10 point bonus and the game ends.  Points are scored for each letter used in words.  The winner is the player with the most points.

Name: Go Tell It on the Mountain
Description:
This is part of the Big Deal series of card games by Patch Products.

Players attempt to collect sets of cards representing various well-known stories from the Bible.

From the Publisher's web site:

Deal the cards, make a mountain and look for matches! Have fun finding matches of classic Bible Stories like: Joseph and His Coat, David and Goliath and The Good Samaritan. In this game that plays like the long-time favorite Go Fish, you'll have fun telling your friends to Go Tell it on the Mountain!

Name: Break Twist
Description: This is somewhat similar to classic Twister. There are footprints of different colors on the play mat and players are going round the mat always stepping on the right colored footprint.

Name: Royal Fluster
Description:
This is part of the Big Deal series of card games by Patch Products.

Players are dealt five cards from a modified standard deck and attempt to put together a Royal Flush by drawing and discarding cards.  If you discard an Ace, you must draw a Fluster card and follow the instructions, hoping not to be harmed.  The first player to make a royal flush wins the game.

Name: Honey Nut Cheerios Spelling Bee Game
Description:
Honey Nut Cheerios Spelling Bee Game is for ages 7 and up, and is a spelling and trivia game.  It includes 150 cards, a spinner (and combination playing surface) and an electronic unit for BuzzBee the mascot.

Licensed by General Mills (the owners of Cheerios breakfast cereal) and published by Briarpatch, this is a kid's "spelling bee" game, with an electronic "host" in the form of "BuzzBee" the Honey Nut Cheerios bee mascot.  The BuzzBee playing piece produces "real studio" sound effects, whatever that means.

Some of the cards are prize cards, and the goal is to answer questions correctly, with the winner being the first to collect 10 cards.

Name: Three Throws
Description:
This is part of the Big Deal series of card games by Patch Products.

This game has a theme of rock-scissors-paper.  It is played in two different rounds.  In the first round, players take turns turning up cards on a face-down tableau.  If they turn up a set of winners, these cards are taken into hand.  When all of the card possible are taken, the second round begins, which is essentially a game of war between players.

Name: Nuts and Bolts
Description: Players attempt to build 3 specific robots by trading for certain robot parts. As parts become scarce, trading becomes more intense. A wrench is thrown into the mix. The player in charge of the wrench decides how many parts will be traded. He also uses the wrench to determine turn order. The first person to build their robots first, wins. Don't forget to do the "Robot" dance when your robot is complete.

Name: Volley & Thunder
Description:
From the games intro:-

WAR IN NAPOLEON’S TIME
Dickens & Greenwood Games are not historical simulation games, such as you may have seen. They are historically based, in that they recreate the military capacities of a given era in the history of warfare, but they are abstract. They do not restrict the player to the circumstances of a given campaign, or to the capacities of actual units, or to the style of an actual leader. Both players are equipped with units whose capacities are equivalent to those of the era in which the game is set. But their forces and situations are abstract and equal, and each player must win or lose according to his own skill and judgment, without the influence of luck or of pre-existing historical conditions. There are no dice or chance outcomes.

Chris's Comments
The game is played on a map divided into equal squares using units to represent Infantry, artillery and Cavalry.  To make the game balanced the map is also symmetric about the line dividing the two sides.  The game is won by either eliminating all field units, or by blocking the roads leading from the opponents city or occupying the opponent city.

Name: Treasure Island
Description:
Welcome to Treasure Island!
it’s on this lonely desert island that Captain Flint one of the boldest buccaneers ever to sail the seven seas, once hid all his treasure. He intended to return to Treasure Island one day to claim his booty, but (like so many pirates) he drank too much rum and didn’t live to
see either the island or his treasure again! Today there are six other adventurers on Treasure Island and each one of them is now searching for Flints fortune. 
They are:-
SQUIRE TRELAWNEY, the owner of the good ship Hispaniola which is moored off the coast of Treasure Island and which has been taken over by its mutinous crew, a band of rascally pirates.
DOCTOR LIVESEY, the ship’s doctor and an old friend of Squire Tretawfley.
CAPTAIN SMOLLETT, the worthy captain of the good ship Hispaniola who has been betrayed by most of his crew.
JIM HAWKINS, who is the cabin boy and one of the bravest lads ever to go to sea.
LONG JOHN SILVER, who is the ship’s cook and the fiercest of all the pirates. To get his hands on the treasure, he will double-cross anyone —even his fellow pirates.
BEN GUNN, who is the wild man of the island and, unlike the others, didn’t arrive on the good ship Hispaniola. Once upon a time Ben Gunn was a member of Captain Flint’s band of
pirates and it was that cruel captain who left him stranded and alone on Treasure Island.

All six are racing to find Flint’s hidden treasure. It’s an exciting race, as you'll discover when you play the Treasure Island game.

Name: LSD: Linearity, Simplicity, Duality
Description:
Warning: This game is only for 2 players or 4 players, not for 2-4 players as described in the summary. You cannot play a 3 player game.

(From publisher's website:) Don't be fooled by the size (10×3.8×3.8 cm), LSD is a complete abstract tile placing game for 2 or 4 players, with no luck involved!

With just an open hand of 20 tiles, try to be the first to get a row of your tiles on the table. Blocking paths, capturing tiles, and reducing the opponents ability to play new tiles are all ways to gain the advantage. Play with 4 players to experience the weirdest 'team play' ever!

Although it is easy to learn, the complexity of this game will definitely surprise you!

Name: Hungry Henry
Description:
Henry, a large plastic bird, swivels on his perch as players attempt to feed various items into his large, hinge-like beak.

Each turn, one item MUST be fed to Henry until it either remains in his beak or causes another object to fall out.  Fallen objects are added to the player's pile of items.

The first player to successfully feed all their items to Henry wins the game.

Name: Auf Achse Junior
Description:
The game board depicts a city map. Each player has a plastic truck which can hold up to four goods (plastic cubes). There are also mission tiles which either ask the player to pick up pieces or to deliver them.
 On a turn, a player rolls a die and moves his/her truck forward the corresponding number of fields. When a truck reaches a building, the player can load or unload goods. There is no 1 on the die, but a stop symbol. A player who rolls this symbol can move the stop sign to any street field, thus blocking the street for all trucks. Trucks can also block each other. The goal of the game is to be the first player to deliver 11 goods.
Families: Versions & Editions: Junior Versions of Grown-Up Games

Name: Drive
Description: Drive "The Exciting Motoring Game - for all the family" Is a road tile lying game from Great Britain. The road tiles are sections of street networks, with traffic signs, hazards, etc… Road tiles can help you or hinder your progress to the finish tile. You start by placing the start and finish cards in the center of the table and lay street tiles to further your cars to the finish tile. First car to the finish tile wins. This game is approved by the Royal society for the Prevention of Accidents.

Name: Tee'd Off
Description: The board is composed of 4 triangles with 15 holes each in them. Each triangle holds 15 of one color wooden golf tees.  The players race to remove the tees by a jumping move until only 1 tee remains on the board.

Name: My First Farm
Description:
Description from the publisher:

By playing My First Farm, a.k.a. Mein erster Bauernhof, children discover the farm. By way of the differently shaped tiles they can check to see whether the tiles match.

The game is made up of 24 tiles, 12 with a red and 12 with a yellow border. The tiles represent activities on a farm as well as things to be found on a farm. There are two sets of rules: one for one child, one for two children. The two children rule is that all tiles are shuffled and put into the middle of the table picture side down. On the first turn a child draws a tile and sees if its his color. If it is he can place it picture side up on his side of the table. If it is not it must be put back into the middle. On subsequent turns the child draws a tile and this must be his color and match the tile/s already placed. If not the tile is put back. A child can choose any tile in the middle including the tile just discarded by the other player. The first one having his twelve farm tiles in a matching row wins.

Name: Starting Lineup Talking Baseball
Description:
In Starting Lineup Talking Baseball, one or two players take on the role(s) of Major League Baseball managers.  Each player tries to out manage his opponent using teams made of up of actual MLB players.

On defense, the manager can choose the pitch type and location.  He can also choose to intentionally walk a player or to bring his infielders in to increase the chances of getting a runner out at home.

On offense, the manager must choose the type of swing (bunt vs. power, for example).  He can also increase the chances for a hit if he can guess the location of the pitch.  The manager may also choose when to attempt a stolen base.

Both managers may, of course, make substitutions.

The game came with All-Star Teams comprised of American League and National League players.  Additional cartridges that contained all 26 MLB teams (as of 1988) were available so that you could play a game between any two teams.

Name: Images
Description:
Exhibited in September 2002 and developed by free jazz artist Peter Brotzmann, Images is a set of 15 cards that questions the boundaries of game as Brotzmann's own music questions the boundaries of form in jazz.  Released with the designer's tenet project.  Each card is meant to be reacted to slowly, one after the other in a sequence.

Integrates with:

    Signs

Name: Impertinent Questions!
Description:
Impertinent Questions is a party game of ridiculous questions and hilarious answers. It can be played by any number of players.

From the game rules:-

It is played with a Pack of 64 Cards, 32 of these cards have two questions printed on each of them and the other 32 have two answers printed on each of them, these two packs must not be mixed. Players sit in two equal rows opposite each other. The Hostess, or person in charge then shuffles each pack separately and proceeds to deal one card from the Question Pack to each player on one side and one card from the Answer pack to each player on the opposite side. FACE DOWNWARDS. The first player on the side to whom the questions have been dealt them turns up his card and asks the player opposite the Question which is printed on the TOP of the card, the player asked then turns up his card and makes the reply printed at the TOP of his card.

Thus question:- "Have you any holes in your stockings?"

Answer:- "Yes but only on Saturday night."

Or again Q :- "Do you ever get drunk?"

A :- "Yes when I am far from home."

Name: Wings over Arras
Description:
Wings over Arras is a card wargame that simulates the World War One air battle over Arras during the British offensive of April 1917. The British Player is trying to carry out air missions over German territory while German the player tries to intercept and destroy them. Successful British missions directly influence the success or failure of the Arras Offensive.

Game Components
• 18 Cards
• 1 Play Mat
• 2,7 pages of rules.

You also need a couple of dice and few markers to play the game.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Forty Niners
Description:
From the box:

The 49ers - An Exciting Game of Risk and Rescue

Interesting game with very spotty rules. A single player takes the role of Blackjack the stagecoach driver who scores points by visiting settlements. The other players take on roles that attempt to thwart his efforts (bandits) or aid him (the sheriff). Once Blackjack has completed the stagecoach circuit, he tallies up points. The board is then rotated 90 degrees and each player takes on a different role. Play continues in such manner until all players have had a chance to play the role of Blackjack at which time the game truly ends and scores are compared. The highest Blackjack score wins.

Their are 4 players. BLACKJACK (Stagecoach Driver),ROARING RED (bandit), BLUEBEARD (bandit) and SHERIFF WHITE

Players play 4 rounds with each player playing a different character in each round. Roaring Red and Bluebeards' objective is to stop the stage coach by using a trail to get in front of the stage. If that happens the stage must turn around and use another trail.

The sheriffs job is to overtake the bandits, he tries to protect the coach and catch the bandits.

Name: Candy
Description:
Candy is played with a bowl of candy and a deck containing twice as many cards as players.  Players attempt to locate Puck (Jack of Spades) while avoiding Grandmother (Queen of Hearts).  Puck allows you to eat the candy you  have collected on previous turns.  Grandmother allows another player to eat your candy.  At the end of each turn, you must take one piece of candy from the bowl and give it to another player and also trade a single card with any player.  The game ends when Puck and Grandmother are discovered in one player's hand or if anyone eats ten pieces of candy.  The player who eats the most candy wins.

Candy is an elaborate descendant of The Lost Pueblo of Doctor Green.  It was first published in the program book of ShoreCon 2000.  It was also published in Chief Herman's Holiday Fun Pack.

Name: Dunkerque
Description:
Dunkerque is a totally new game design, based on Dana Lombardy's original 1972 Dunkerque: 1940 game, which featured big hexes, large counters with no combat factors and hidden movement, and a unit comparison table instead of dice for combat resolution. This division-level game explores possibilities in the 1940 campaign in France, including: Could German panzers cut off and destroy the British Expeditionary Force? Were the extended panzer columns vulnerable to an Allied counter stroke?

While the game’s core content is strongly derived from Dunkerque 1940, the game system and visual approach are totally new. This new graphic approach ties in with 3D components and revised game mechanics to provide a robust, realistic, yet streamlined game.

Dunkerque’s primary new design features:


     Block system hidden movement
     Color codes for unit quality and movement
     Combat resolution using custom six-sided dice
     Actual terrain map
     Cards in place of air and naval units
     Cards to help determine attacks, defense, random events, etc. 


With the demise of Last Stand Games, it is unclear when the game would be released and under which publisher.

Name: Warfare in the Age of Discovery
Description: This is a set of miniatures wargaming rules for the Renaissance, (1470-1680).  It also includes rules for the English Civil War.

Name: Geloof 't of niet
Description:
From the publisher:

More and more people are taking an interest in each other's faith. This game makes religion accessible to everyone. Knowledge leads to understanding and understanding leads to tolerance. And it's fun too! Geloof 't of niet: the children's game about the most important religions in the world! Fascinating, topical and instructive.

Name: Oorlogs-spel
Description:
The name of the game is "wargame" translated in English. This game was published in the Netherlands somewhere between 1880 and 1900 (judging by the material used, the publisher and the uniforms in the picture). It was published by a cookie factory for marketing purposes.

The background of the board is an illustration of Dutch troops attacking a revolting native town in the Dutch East Indies colony (probably in Atjeh). There are 90 numbered dots (white and red) on the board, the rules are printed in the lower left and lower right corners.

The game is is played like Game of Goose, with 2 dice and pawns. Each player rolls two dice to decide who goes first(highest roll starts). The rest of the players take their turn clockwise. Each turn a player rolls two dice and moves his pawn according to his roll.

At the start of the game every player pays ten chips to the bank. Whenever a player ends his move on a white dot nothing happens and the next player gets to roll the dice. The red dots are 'special event' dots. These events may be positive or negative for the player. For instance: roll again, get wounded (and move backwards to the hospital) or get killed (and have to start all over again). In most of these cases the player also pays chips to or receives chips from the bank.

The winner is the first player to reach nr. 90; the dot at the heart of the native town. This player is honored with the Ridder Kruis (Knight's Cross) and receives all chips in the bank.

Name: V
Description:
V - "Join in and relive the fantastic adventure to save the Earth"

Cheap and cheerful Spanish spin-off board game for the younger gamers, cashing in on the 1983 American TV series of the same name that had audiences across the globe glued to their TV sets.

"One day, 50 space ships appear across different earth locations, that in a matter of days are conquered, for the sole purpose of stripping the earth of its water and (human) food supplies. In order to fight them a resistance group called "V" is set up, which embarks on the obvious route of liberating all the cities dominated by the invaders. But the visitors are prepared and have set tough traps in their way.

The first player who is able to overcome all the obstacles and reach the city where one can find the ship of the extraterrestrial supreme commander, not only saves the earth but also wins the game."

It comes with a board, 1 UFO spinner, 6 cardboard figurines and 12 cards.

Publishing history: Published in Spain in 1984 as a cheap and cheerful spin off from the popular American sci-fi tv-series.

Name: Saggsen-Gadan: De säggs'schn Siedler / Catan-OFFENSIVE in Chemnitz
Description:
"Saggsen Gadan, de Säggs'schen Siedler" or "Saggsen Gadan, the Settlers of Sax'ny"

What do you do when 2 major German game institutions both celebrate a 10 year anniversary in the same year? You throw one heck of a party and you invite all who want to come and join in. And when they leave, you give them a thank-you present.

On the 10th of September 2005, the Deutsche Spielemuseum (the German Game Museum and brainchild of Peter Lemcke) celebrated in style in its current hometown of Chemnitz, in the German state of Saxony, by attempting to break a world record in conjunction with that other birthday kid, the "Settlers of Catan". A more than 300 meter long game table was erected, offering room for 1000 Settler players, who all could participate on one gigantic Settlers map, using 17,500 Settlers' hexagons in the process. As it happened, 816 participants sat down to invade the ribbon island and the record stood.

To mark the occasion, a commemorative Settler expansion, themed on the German state of Saxony, was issued by Kosmos, in a limited edition of 1000, one for each participant. Klaus Teuber was on hand to sign his life away.

Saggsen Gadan presented two new scenarios for Settlers, both requiring game pieces from the basic set to play. Special game pieces needed for these Saxony scenarios were also included, ready to cut out. Instead of the usual variable game-set-up of the basic game, the two scenarios both use a ready-made map. There is one scenario map printed on each side of the expansion sheet, in the same vein as the game boards from boxed historical theme set expansions.

1. Saggsen-Gadan:
For this game variant, players must colonize Saggsen using the usual building and resource trading mechanisms. Through progressive development, different manufacturers can be founded, whose products subsequently can be turned into victory points. But be warned: Saggsen is sliced up by many rivers, that can only be crossed at bridges. To become King of Saggsen you will have to make your influence count in the seven regions of the state. Who is the first to obtain 10 victory points?

2. Catan-Offensive in Chemnitz - a quick scenario for 2-3 players:
By utilizing the resources obtained through building and trading, players aim to populate the city of Chemnitz bit by bit. As the game progresses, players can obtain colorful postcards of historical buildings, museums and leisure facilities. These postcards can then be exchanged for victory points. Karl Marx, after whom the city was known in its East German days when it was called Karl-Marx-Stadt, now takes over the role of Joker/Robber.

Belongs to the Catan Series.

Expands:

    CATAN

Name: Basketball
Description: This early game from Warren Built-Rite Games is numbered 883. Use cards to move your players up and down the court to score. Game is for age 8 and up. It comes with 2 Markers, Game Court, Cardboard Clock to keep track of time during the game and a Cardboard Basketball to keep track of where the ball is located on the court.

Name: Allaboutfootball
Description:
ALLABOUTFOOTBALL is a Trivia type board game dedicated to English football. There is a general English version, and bespoke versions for Chelsea, Arsenal, Manchester United, Liverpool, Tottenham Hotspur, Glasgow Rangers and Glasgow Celtic.

Game play design incorporates strategic decision making with a football trivia knowledge.
 Contents: game board, one special die & one standard die, 18 x substitution cards, 6 x player tokens, 300 x trivia question cards

Name: Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #1 – Greece & Eastern Kingdoms
Description:
The Greeks & Eastern Kingdoms is the first expansion to Commands & Colors: Ancients. The armies of Philip, Alexander and the Successors meet the hosts of Persians, Scythians and Indians to the east. In this expansion, you will find historical scenarios that focus on the hoplites of classical Greece fighting off the invading Persian army at Marathon and Plataea; epic battles from the Peloponnesian War, the rise of Macedon and Alexander's battles of Gaugamela, Issus and Granicus against the Persians; and battles involving Alexander's successors. With your Greeks you will be able to turn west and battle the Carthaginians in Sicily, or as King Pyrrhus at Heraclea and Ausculum, battle the Romans.

This first expansion showcases over 20 scenarios (the package includes over 300 new unit blocks and stickers you need to fight out these battles). Now, that is a lot of history, but Commands & Colors: Ancients is, by design, a unique historical game system that will allow players to effectively portray stylized Ancient battles that play to a conclusion in less than an hour.

The battle dice resolve combat quickly and the command cards provide an element of luck that creates a fog of war and presents players with both challenges and opportunities for victory. Yet the tactics you need to execute conform remarkably well to the advantages and limitations inherent to the various Ancient units, their weapons, terrain and the history.

Expands:

    Commands & Colors: Ancients
Families: History: Greek & Persian conflicts of the 4th century BC
History: Wars of Alexander the Great
History: Wars of the Diadochi and Syrian Wars

Name: Gang War
Description: In this Axis & Allies variant, players get to simulate gang wars in '80s and '90s Los Angeles between five rival gangs - Bloods, Crypts, Hell's Angels, Latin Kings, and the Mafia.  Includes map, 1D10, over 270 unit counters, and 36 building counters.

Name: Whitechapel 1888
Description:
"WHITECHAPEL 1888 - Jack the Ripper's Playground."

A board game based on events which took place in the East End of London in 1888.
For 3 to 6 players aged 12+.
One player takes the role of "Jack the Ripper" and the others one of his 5 potential victims.
The object of the game is for the ladies to escape Jack's clutches and to reach the safety of Scotland Yard Police Station. Jack wins if he eliminates the ladies and evades capture by the police.
There is an option for a seventh player to play the role of "PC White" during the game's concluding phase.

The game consists of cards, dice, pawns, and game board.

Devised by Andy and Sue Parlour.

Name: Liubo
Description:
Ancient Chinese game dating back to at least 400BC or perhaps even as far back as 700 BC. The game maybe connected to the later Xiangqi, Nyout and some race games like Ashtapada, representing cosmological and religious patterns, used also for divination.

The rules are forgotten, but many pictures and artifacts, even records of single divinations made with the same board, have been found, and there is a playable "reconstructed" version by chess-expert and author Jean-Louis Cazaux http://history.chess.free.fr/liubo-rules.htm.

The board is a square with an unusual pattern of lines and angles on it, equally on each side. There is also a central square. The moves of the six figures (five "pawns" and one "king") of the two players are determined by throwing marked sticks, probably not by only counting some marks but also interpreting and calculating the throw according to some rules derived from the Yijing.

Winner is the one who captures all of his opponent's stones.

Name: EuroGame
Description:
"A trivia game for people who keep up with the times - A game that knows no borders"

A trivia game about Europe. There are 2 different difficulty levels on the questions and the idea is to get flags of 6 different countries and the get back to the central point of the board from where the players started their journey.

Name: Eastern Front (fan expansion for Axis & Allies: Europe)
Description: This is an unauthorized expansion and variant kit for Axis & Allies: Europe:   It contains additional plastic playing pieces plus an expansion including technology development, special historical rules, Italian and Axis minor special forces, marines, panzers, and more.

Name: Futebol Business
Description:
Football (soccer) game, where the goal is to be as rich as possible. You are the trainer and the manager of your team. For that you buy/sell players and play a soccer game with cards.
The player's names are real.

Name: Les Voyages d'Astérix
Description: The game is played by acquiring counters and goods in the cities of the Roman Empire. The counters and goods can be sold between players and sold to the bank. The rich players will be able to increase their profits by paying for the services of a robber who will ransom his adversaries. The winner will be the one who has eliminated the other players and increased their capital, their goods and their counters.

Name: Build
Description:
This is a special niche kind of a game. The game was created for the Ancient Accepted Scottish Rite, Northern Masonic Jurisdiction in Lexington MA. by  Whitehall Games Inc. It is based on the ideals of Masonic Freemasonry.

from the box: The object of the game is to complete building your trestle board from the Rough Ashlar to the Perfect Ashlar as you progress from Entered Apprentice through Fellowcraft to Master Mason.

The game contains; 4 Trestle Boards, 36 Cards and 136 Playing Stones

Name: Round the Horn
Description:
"Round the Horn" re-creates the annual race of grain-laden, square-rigged sailing cargo ships from Australia to London.

In the first phase of the game, each player draws Loading cards and discarding them until he has a "Lloyd's Certificate" designating the color of his craft and the amount of grain he must carry. Once a player has a certificate, he draws and keeps (or discards) Loading cards until he has the exact amount of cargo required.

Once fully loaded, a player enters the second phase of the game -- sailing. A player under sail chooses a sail state (full, 3/4, 1/2, storm), then draws a card and checks the resulting combination on their sailing wheel. There is a Total Loss card which, if followed by a second draw indicating bad weather or other calamity, can damage the player's ship or force him out of the game entirely.

The first player to arrive safely in London is the winner.

No copyright date is given, but a London game collector asserts the vintage for this game to be of the early 1930s. The subject matter is consistent with this estimate, in light of the Great Grain Race of 1932, and the box style (i.e., small label fixed to larger cover) fits that of the 1930s.

Name: A Bit O' Blarney
Description:
Fitting the mold of 1980's vintage trivia games of the, "A Bit O' Blarney" challenges its players with the literature, geography, history, legends, and other cultural aspects of Ireland. Players draw a card for their question number, choose a category, try to answer the matching question in the book, and -- if successful -- roll the die, advance, and repeat the procedure. A wrong answer ends the player's turn. Some spaces on the board force a player to answer from a specific category, though the player is limited to this constraint for only three unsuccessful turns.

The winner is the first to arrive at Blarney, "and his prize is the life-long gift of eloquence."

Ideally the game is for two to six players, though its inventor notes that the game may be played solo. Six cardboard "elves" are provided, but the inventor add that it may also be played by more than six people by adding "shirt buttons or pennies" for the other players to move with.

Finally, the game contains an optional 1-hour tape of Irish music and dance, recorded live during a summer ethnic festival in Baltimore.

Name: Coolball
Description:
You try to roll small balls on the other side of the board and score points. You score points depending on the area the ball lands. In one area you get bonus balls. The game lasts over 3 winning sets, with 3 tries per player each set.

This game is the re-incarnation of Magoo, that was presented at Essen in 1995 in 3 editions: a deluxe edition made of beech wood, a popular edition , and a variant that was played on a roll-up mat.

Name: Treasure Hunt
Description:
Swashbuckling adventure game with 4 magnetic sailing ships, colorful metal board & spinner.

Exciting magnetic game, wonderful for travel, sick bed, and regular play.

Name: Who's in the Igloo?
Description:
Igloo Game contents:
The Movable Igloo
15 Eskimo Cards
Game Instructions Card
 Idea of the Game:
Move the Igloo to collect the Eskimos but watch out, the Polar Bear might get you.
 The Game:
Slide the Igloo around and collect the Eskimo Cards. If you can keep an Eskimo in the entrance you can keep moving but if a Polar Bear appears it becomes the next player's turn.
 The Polar Bears are everywhere but you can avoid them with a good memory and a little luck.

Name: Choice
Description:
A collection of games played on boards which fit into a plastic holder. The plastic surface had a grid of holes in it, some of which were exposed by holes in the boards. A set of generic pegs were used to play the games.

The original edition of the game from MBC Nome Company had twenty different game boards. Thirteen of these were sold in three boxed sets containing six boards each: a "Family Assortment," "Children's Assortment," and "Adult Assortment" (with overlap between the sets). Seven more boards were listed on the side of the boxed sets as "Individual Games" and were presumably sold separately. The rulebook provided with the boxed sets contained rules for all thirteen games in the assortments plus a fourteenth game, Five in a Row, which was played directly on the plastic grid.

The Avalon Hill edition of the game was sold in boxed sets which each had a random set of six games; it is not clear how many of the MBC Nome games were re-used.

Name: Väripeli
Description: An educational game to teach colors and train memorizing skills for small children. There 5 cards of each of 5 colors and a color die included.

Name: Gala
Description:
Gala, also knows as "farmer's chess" or "pagan chess" was a game played in some farmers villages in northern Germany. The game probably comes from the middle ages. It has been mentioned in the game books by R. C. Bell, Jack Botermans / Pieter van Delft and Glonnegger.

The game is played on a board of ten by ten squares. The four corners of four by four squares are distinguished by a line, thus shaping a cross two lines wide, consisting of the  rows 5 and 6 and/or the columns e and f. These lines are called deflection lines.
Each player has eight Kampas (pawns), five Horsas and Kornas and two Galas (kings), placed like this:
White:
Gala a1, j1; Korna a3, b2, c1, i1, j2; Horsa a2, b1, h1, i2, j3; Kampa a4, b3, c2, d1, g1, h2, i3, j4. 
Black:
Gala a10, j10; Korna a9, b10, h10, i9, j8; Horsa a8, b9, c10, i10, j9; Kampa a7, b8, c9, d10, g10, h9, i8, j7.

Galas move in general as kings in chess. Additionally, when a Gala is on one of the four squares in the middle of the board, it may be moved in one move to any empty square on the board with the exception of those squares that contain a piece in the opening setup. Kings can only take when moving over a deflection line. 
A Korna moves as a rook in chess when in a corner of the board, and as a bishop in the middle of the board. It is also possible to combine these moves in one turn! Kornas can only take in moves where they move over a deflection line. 
Horsas are just the opposite of Kornas (with an additional small difference in the taking rules): they move as bishops on the corner parts, and as rooks on the middle part. Again it is possible to combine such moves. Horsas only take in moves where they pass the deflection line, but not when they move only one square in rookwise fashion.
Kampas move diagonally towards the middle of the board until they are in the middle part or in the opponents corners. It is allowed to move two squares if the deflection line isn't passed with the first move of the Kampa. When the Kampa is in the middle part or in one of the opponents corners, then it may move one square in any direction. When a Kampa is moved back to a corner of the owning player, it can only move diagonally forward again. Kampas only can take in the move after they have crossed a deflection line.

When a player threatens a king of the opponent, he says: Gala! The opponent must defend the king, if possible. Otherwise, the player takes the king of the opponent. One wins the game by taking both kings of the opponent. 
When only two kings of different players are left on the board, the game is a draw.

There are different variants discussed in the internet concerning the moves and the winning (defining another goal in placing the Galas in the 4 squares in the very middle of the board).

Name: The Book of Pop-Up Board Games
Description: There are four pop-up board games in this book. The games are, Space Escape, Pirate Treasure, Mummy Chase, & Save the Princess. Each game has a storage pocket to store the stand-up people. There is also a fold out spinner, that you use to move.
